channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Fee Faces Lawsuit
item.description: California and New York are among the states arguing that the Trump administration’s decision to charge that fee for skilled foreign workers is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump after signing a proclamation instituting the visa fee for some foreign workers in September.

item.title: Judge’s Order Complicates Justice Dept. Plans to Again Charge Comey
item.description: Justice Department officials have been considering whether to bring new charges against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, after a different judge dismissed the original case against him.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Monica Jorge for The New York Times
item.media:description: A judge’s order suggested that sloppiness by the Justice Department had helped to sabotage President Trump’s demands to use the criminal justice system to go after James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.

item.title: Government Can Withhold Funds From Planned Parenthood, Appeals Court Rules
item.description: A three-judge panel threw out a lower court’s order, allowing the Trump administration to continue defunding the group and other major abortion providers.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Planned Parenthood has said that if allowed to take effect, the provision could lead to closures of the organization’s health clinics and decimate its budget.

item.title: U.S. Boarded Ship and Seized Cargo Heading to Iran From China
item.description: The seizure last month came amid fears of a renewed conflict between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tingshu Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: Yantian port in Shenzhen, China. The United States had been tracking cargo as it made its way from China to Iran.

item.title: House G.O.P. Releases Health Plan That Would Allow Subsidies to End
item.description: The legislation, expected to come to a vote next week, would make changes that could eventually affect health care costs but are unlikely to immediately curb rising premiums.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: After False Earthquake Alert in Nevada, Lawmakers Demand Answers on How it Was Sent
item.description: The federal government and earthquake experts blamed a technical glitch for the alert that sent warnings hundreds of miles away last week.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Emily Najera for The New York Times
item.media:description: The outskirts of Reno, Nev. Last week an early warning system set off a false alarm for an earthquake nearby.

item.title: Behind the Venezuelan Opposition Leader’s Daring Escape to Oslo
item.description: An American firm with experience in special operations spirited María Corina Machado, the recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, out of the country in a secretive land, sea and air operation.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Leonhard Foeger/Reuters
item.media:description: María Corina Machado spent the last year hiding from President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela’s regime.

item.title: National Guardsman Who Was Shot in D.C. Making ‘Extraordinary Progress,’ Doctor Says
item.description: Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, who suffered a head wound in the shooting near the White House last month, has moved from acute care to rehabilitation.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in honor of Specialist Sarah Beckstrom and Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe in Washington.

item.title: Trump Faces Same Demons as Biden: Age, Health and the Economy
item.description: Too old? Tough economy? The presidents change, but the troubles are familiar.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has recently faced questions about his health and handling of the economy.

item.title: Trump Officials Sue to Seize 2020 Ballots in a Georgia County
item.description: The Justice Department escalated an effort to seize and inspect old ballots in Fulton County, where President Trump was booked in his criminal election interference case.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers during the Fulton County ballot recount in Atlanta in November 2020.

item.title: For Republicans, Trump’s Hands-Off Approach to Health Care Is a Problem
item.description: The prospect of soaring health care costs could exacerbate Americans’ feelings about affordability, an issue that President Trump has tried to downplay. But Democrats plan to keep the issue front and center.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said Thursday night that he may soon start negotiating with Democrats to lower health care costs.

item.title: In Florida’s Panhandle, a Hearing on School Vaccine Mandates Gets Heated
item.description: The hearing was the first concrete step toward repealing some of the state’s vaccine requirements. Rolling back others would require legislative action.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Brendan Farrington
item.media:credit: Kate Payne/Associated Press
item.media:description: Larry Downs Jr. speaks against childhood vaccine mandates at a public hearing held by Florida’s Department of Health on Friday in Panama City Beach, Fla.

item.title: For Rubio the Cuba Hawk, the Road to Havana Runs Through Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s secretary of state and national security adviser has long sought to cripple or topple Cuba’s government, which has close security and economic ties to Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s parents immigrated to Florida from Havana three years before Cuba’s communist revolution prevailed in 1959.

item.title: Scenes From Washington After a Week of Torrential Rain and Flooding
item.description: More than 100,000 residents were told to leave their homes across Washington State this week as rivers overflowed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue crews from Spokane combed through floodwaters near SR-20 in Burlington, Wash., on Friday.

item.title: National Parks Ordered to Remove Items Promoting D.E.I. From Gift Shops
item.description: The Interior Department said that the review of retail items would ensure gift shops at national parks did not “promote specific viewpoints.”
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zion Canyon Visitor Center at Zion National Park in Utah in August.

item.title: T.S.A. Is Providing Air Passenger Data to Immigration Agents for Deportation Effort
item.description: The Transportation Security Administration is providing passenger lists to Immigrations and Customs Enforcement to identify and detain travelers subject to deportation orders.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times

item.title: In Trump’s Justice Dept., Failing in Court Might Be Better Than Bucking the Boss
item.description: Thursday demonstrated an emerging reality for President Trump: Commanding the Justice Department is not the same as controlling the justice system.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: The White House was served a legal rebuke this week when federal grand jurors in Alexandria, Va., rejected the Justice Department’s push to indict Letitia James, the New York attorney general, on mortgage-related charges for the second time in a week.

item.title: Harvard Replaces Leader of Health Center Said to Have Focused on Palestinians
item.description: The center at the university’s public health school was also a focus of the Trump administration after having been examined in a Harvard antisemitism report earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The François-Xavier Bagnoud Center for Health and Human Rights at Harvard’s public health school will have new leadership. An interim was named in the meantime.

item.title: Transportation Dept. Threatens to Withhold Funds From N.Y. Over Noncitizen Licenses
item.description: The Trump administration gave New York 30 days to pause issuing all non-domiciled commercial driver’s licenses, among other demands, or risk losing $73 million in highway funds.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said New York’s commercial driver’s license standards represented “a systematically grossly unacceptable deviation from federal safety regulations.”

item.title: Appeals Court Halts, for Now, Contempt Inquiry Into Deportation Flights
item.description: The decision from the three-judge panel served to grant the Trump administration a reprieve from having one of its top immigration lawyers have to take the witness stand next week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department’s request to the appeals court was not the first time it had sought to involve appellate judges in derailing the contempt investigation.

item.title: Alvin Holsey, Admiral Who Oversaw Boat Strikes Off Venezuela’s Coast, Retires
item.description: The admiral had abruptly announced that he would step down as the head of the U.S. Southern Command. His departure leaves several issues about the strikes unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Rebecca Blackwell/Associated Press
item.media:description: Adm. Alvin Holsey, right, became the latest in a line of at least two dozen military leaders, many of them people of color and women, who have left their jobs this year.

item.title: National Trust Sues to Block Trump’s White House Ballroom Construction
item.description: The lawsuit seeks to force President Trump to submit his ballroom plans for public review and input.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump ordered the demolition the entire East Wing of the White House in October to make way for a 90,000-square-foot ballroom.

item.title: Businesses Are Cashing In on Trump’s Tax Cuts
item.description: Corporate tax revenue has quickly dipped since Republicans passed tax cuts this summer. But economists think these tax breaks might be worth it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: While Americans won’t begin to see tax savings until next year, some corporations, including Walmart, are already reporting reductions to their tax payments in 2025.

item.title: Record Flooding Swamps Western Washington
item.description: Gov. Bob Ferguson and other state officials cautioned that more rainfall was expected after rivers hit record flood levels across the region, while residents worried about the long-term future.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin, Amy Graff and Drew Atkins
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Floodwaters overtook Skykomish River Park and some nearby apartments in Monroe, Wash., on Thursday night.

item.title: Comics Performing in Hindi Are Selling Out Shows Across the U.S.
item.description: America is becoming a second home for Hindi comedy.
item.dc:creator: Saurabh Datar
item.media:credit: Krimesh Patel
item.media:description: The comedian Zakir Zhan

item.title: New Photos From Epstein Estate Show Ties to Trump, Clinton and More Powerful Men
item.description: The images, released without context by Democrats on the House Oversight Committee, revealed little new about the deceased sex offender’s ties to prominent men in politics, entertainment and finance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein, center, in court in West Palm Beach, Fla., in 2008. Wealthy and famous men once in his orbit have faced questions about what they knew about the accusations that he was trafficking girls.

item.title: Troops Involved in Boat Strikes Face a ‘Moral Injury’ Risk, Experts Say
item.description: Troops who play a part in deadly missions that they see as wrong or unjustified may suffer deep psychological harm as a result, research has shown.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Each deadly strike involves numerous military personnel who may be at risk of psychological harm.

item.title: Behind the Supreme Court’s Push to Expand Presidential Power
item.description: For more than a decade, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority has chipped away at Congress’s power to insulate independent agencies from politics. Now, the court has signaled its willingness to expand presidential power once again.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow, Claire Hogan, Stephanie Swart and Pierre Kattar

item.title: Kids Rarely Read Whole Books Anymore. Even in English Class.
item.description: When teachers do assign whole books, they often choose from a stagnant list of classics.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
